events.title: Transporting the Treasure and Its Diverse Nature
detailed_summary: The group undertook the arduous task of moving the substantial treasure from the cave to the Hispaniola, a mile by land and three by sea.
The three remaining mutineers on the island caused little concern, with a single lookout deemed sufficient protection.
Work progressed efficiently: Gray and Ben Gunn ferried treasure by boat, while others, during the boat's absence, accumulated treasure on the beach.
Jim, considered not strong enough for heavy carrying, spent his days in the cave organizing and packing the various coins into bread-bags.
He was captivated by the extraordinary diversity of the coinage, reminiscent of Billy Bones's collection but far larger and more varied.

The collection included currencies from England, France, Spain, and Portugal, featuring images of European monarchs from the past century, alongside peculiar Oriental coins with unusual markings, and pieces of different shapes, some even pierced for wearing.
Jim felt that nearly every type of money in existence was represented, their sheer quantity like autumn leaves, causing him physical strain from bending and sorting.
This labor continued daily, with a significant amount of treasure moved to the ship each evening, yet much more always remained for the next day, all without any sign from the three mutineers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next morning we fell early to work, for the transportation of this great mass of gold near a mile by land to the beach, and thence three miles by boat to the Hispaniola, was a considerable task for so small a number of workmen.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Day after day this work went on; by every evening a fortune had been stowed aboard, but there was another fortune waiting for the morrow; and all this time we heard nothing of the three surviving mutineers.

events.text_segment:
The next morning we fell early to work, for the transportation of this great mass of gold near a mile by land to the beach, and thence three miles by boat to the Hispaniola, was a considerable task for so small a number of workmen. The three fellows still abroad upon the island did not greatly trouble us; a single sentry on the shoulder of the hill was sufficient to ensure us against any sudden onslaught, and we thought, besides, they had had more than enough of fighting.
Therefore the work was pushed on briskly. Gray and Ben Gunn came and went with the boat, while the rest during their absences piled treasure on the beach. Two of the bars, slung in a rope’s end, made a good load for a grown man—one that he was glad to walk slowly with. For my part, as I was not much use at carrying, I was kept busy all day in the cave packing the minted money into bread-bags.
It was a strange collection, like Billy Bones’s hoard for the diversity of coinage, but so much larger and so much more varied that I think I never had more pleasure than in sorting them. English, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Georges, and Louises, doubloons and double guineas and moidores and sequins, the pictures of all the kings of Europe for the last hundred years, strange Oriental pieces stamped with what looked like wisps of string or bits of spider’s web, round pieces and square pieces, and pieces bored through the middle, as if to wear them round your neck—nearly every variety of money in the world must, I think, have found a place in that collection; and for number, I am sure they were like autumn leaves, so that my back ached with stooping and my fingers with sorting them out.
Day after day this work went on; by every evening a fortune had been stowed aboard, but there was another fortune waiting for the morrow; and all this time we heard nothing of the three surviving mutineers.

events.title: Eerie Sounds from Mutineers and Silver's Ambiguous Counsel
detailed_summary: One evening, while the Doctor and Jim were walking on a hill overlooking the island's lowlands, they heard unsettling sounds, a mixture of screams and songs, carried by the wind from the darkness below.
The Doctor identified the noises as coming from the mutineers.
Silver, who had been granted complete freedom and was persistently attempting to regain favor, appeared and suggested the mutineers were drunk.

Jim reflected on Silver's peculiar status: though free, he was generally treated with contempt by most, except for Ben Gunn who still feared him, and Jim himself who felt a complex mix of gratitude and suspicion, especially having witnessed Silver's earlier contemplation of betrayal.
The Doctor responded curtly to Silver, stating the men were either drunk or delirious.
Silver concurred, adding that the distinction mattered little to their own safety.
The Doctor then expressed a surprising humanitarian impulse, saying if he were certain the men were delirious from fever, he would risk his own safety to provide medical help.
Silver strongly advised against this, arguing the mutineers were untrustworthy and would undoubtedly kill the Doctor, thereby weakening their party, and stressed his current allegiance to them.
The Doctor replied with sarcasm, alluding to Silver's own questionable reliability.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last—I think it was on the third night—the doctor and I were strolling on the shoulder of the hill where it overlooks the lowlands of the isle, when, from out the thick darkness below, the wind brought us a noise between shrieking and singing.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “No,” said the doctor. “You’re the man to keep your word, we know that.”

events.text_segment:
At last—I think it was on the third night—the doctor and I were strolling on the shoulder of the hill where it overlooks the lowlands of the isle, when, from out the thick darkness below, the wind brought us a noise between shrieking and singing. It was only a snatch that reached our ears, followed by the former silence.
“Heaven forgive them,” said the doctor; “’tis the mutineers!”
“All drunk, sir,” struck in the voice of Silver from behind us.
Silver, I should say, was allowed his entire liberty, and in spite of daily rebuffs, seemed to regard himself once more as quite a privileged and friendly dependent. Indeed, it was remarkable how well he bore these slights and with what unwearying politeness he kept on trying to ingratiate himself with all. Yet, I think, none treated him better than a dog, unless it was Ben Gunn, who was still terribly afraid of his old quartermaster, or myself, who had really something to thank him for; although for that matter, I suppose, I had reason to think even worse of him than anybody else, for I had seen him meditating a fresh treachery upon the plateau. Accordingly, it was pretty gruffly that the doctor answered him.
“Drunk or raving,” said he.
“Right you were, sir,” replied Silver; “and precious little odds which, to you and me.”
“I suppose you would hardly ask me to call you a humane man,” returned the doctor with a sneer, “and so my feelings may surprise you, Master Silver. But if I were sure they were raving—as I am morally certain one, at least, of them is down with fever—I should leave this camp, and at whatever risk to my own carcass, take them the assistance of my skill.”
“Ask your pardon, sir, you would be very wrong,” quoth Silver. “You would lose your precious life, and you may lay to that. I’m on your side now, hand and glove; and I shouldn’t wish for to see the party weakened, let alone yourself, seeing as I know what I owes you. But these men down there, they couldn’t keep their word—no, not supposing they wished to; and what’s more, they couldn’t believe as you could.”
“No,” said the doctor. “You’re the man to keep your word, we know that.”

events.title: Decision to Abandon Mutineers and Final Departure Preparations
detailed_summary: The group heard little more from the three remaining pirates, apart from a distant gunshot once, which they assumed was from the pirates hunting.
A formal council was convened, and the decision was made to abandon the mutineers on the island.
Ben Gunn was immensely pleased by this outcome, and Gray also showed strong support for the decision.

A substantial quantity of supplies was left for the stranded men, including gunpowder, ammunition, the majority of their salted goat meat, some medicines, tools, clothing, a spare sail, rope, and, at the Doctor's specific request, a generous portion of tobacco.
This provisioning was one of their final acts on the island.
Prior to these events, they had completed the task of stowing all the treasure aboard the Hispaniola, and had also loaded sufficient water and the rest of the goat meat for their journey.
Finally, on a clear morning, they managed the difficult task of weighing anchor and sailed out of North Inlet, flying the same flag under which the captain had defended the stockade.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, that was about the last news we had of the three pirates.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Before that, we had got the treasure stowed and had shipped enough water and the remainder of the goat meat in case of any distress; and at last, one fine morning, we weighed anchor, which was about all that we could manage, and stood out of North Inlet, the same colours flying that the captain had flown and fought under at the palisade.

events.text_segment:
Well, that was about the last news we had of the three pirates. Only once we heard a gunshot a great way off and supposed them to be hunting. A council was held, and it was decided that we must desert them on the island—to the huge glee, I must say, of Ben Gunn, and with the strong approval of Gray. We left a good stock of powder and shot, the bulk of the salt goat, a few medicines, and some other necessaries, tools, clothing, a spare sail, a fathom or two of rope, and by the particular desire of the doctor, a handsome present of tobacco.
That was about our last doing on the island. Before that, we had got the treasure stowed and had shipped enough water and the remainder of the goat meat in case of any distress; and at last, one fine morning, we weighed anchor, which was about all that we could manage, and stood out of North Inlet, the same colours flying that the captain had flown and fought under at the palisade.

events.title: The Mutineers' Desperate Plea and Parting Shot
detailed_summary: It became apparent that the three abandoned mutineers had been observing the Hispaniola's departure more closely than the crew had realized.
As the ship navigated a narrow passage near the island's southern point, the crew saw the three men kneeling together on a spit of sand, their arms raised in a gesture of supplication.

The sight deeply affected everyone on board, but the risk of inciting another mutiny, coupled with the grim alternative of transporting them to England for execution, prevented any consideration of rescue.
The Doctor called out to the mutineers, informing them about the provisions that had been left for them and their location.
Despite this, the men continued to implore for mercy, desperately begging not to be left to die in such a desolate place.

As the Hispaniola continued its course and moved out of earshot, one of the mutineers—Jim could not identify which—leapt to his feet with a hoarse cry, aimed his musket, and fired a shot that whistled past Silver's head and tore through the mainsail.
After this hostile act, the crew took cover behind the ship's bulwarks.
When Jim next looked, the mutineers had disappeared from the sand spit, and the spit itself was rapidly fading into the growing distance.
By noon, to Jim's profound relief, the highest point of Treasure Island had vanished below the horizon.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The three fellows must have been watching us closer than we thought for, as we soon had proved.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That was, at least, the end of that; and before noon, to my inexpressible joy, the highest rock of Treasure Island had sunk into the blue round of sea.

events.text_segment:
The three fellows must have been watching us closer than we thought for, as we soon had proved. For coming through the narrows, we had to lie very near the southern point, and there we saw all three of them kneeling together on a spit of sand, with their arms raised in supplication. It went to all our hearts, I think, to leave them in that wretched state; but we could not risk another mutiny; and to take them home for the gibbet would have been a cruel sort of kindness. The doctor hailed them and told them of the stores we had left, and where they were to find them. But they continued to call us by name and appeal to us, for God’s sake, to be merciful and not leave them to die in such a place.
At last, seeing the ship still bore on her course and was now swiftly drawing out of earshot, one of them—I know not which it was—leapt to his feet with a hoarse cry, whipped his musket to his shoulder, and sent a shot whistling over Silver’s head and through the main-sail.
After that, we kept under cover of the bulwarks, and when next I looked out they had disappeared from the spit, and the spit itself had almost melted out of sight in the growing distance. That was, at least, the end of that; and before noon, to my inexpressible joy, the highest rock of Treasure Island had sunk into the blue round of sea.

The three fellows must have been watching us closer than we thought for, as we soon had proved. It went to all our hearts, I think, to leave them in that wretched state; but we could not risk another mutiny; and to take them home for the gibbet would have been a cruel sort of kindness. The doctor hailed them and told them of the stores we had left, and where they were to find them. But they continued to call us by name and appeal to us, for God’s sake, to be merciful and not leave them to die in such a place.

At last, seeing the ship still bore on her course and was now swiftly drawing out of earshot, one of them—I know not which it was—leapt to his feet with a hoarse cry, whipped his musket to his shoulder, and sent a shot whistling over Silver’s head and through the mainsail.

After that, we kept under cover of the bulwarks, and when I looked again they were already no bigger than dolls, and soon, to my great relief, they had vanished altogether. The spit of sand was drowned in the growing distance. And so, before noon, to my infinite joy, the highest rock of Treasure Island had sunk into the blue round of sea.

events.title: Challenging Voyage to Spanish America and Welcoming Arrival
detailed_summary: The Hispaniola was severely understaffed, necessitating that everyone capable contribute to sailing the ship, with only Captain Smollett, still recuperating but much improved, directing operations from a mattress in the stern.
They set course for the nearest port in Spanish America, deeming it too risky to attempt the voyage home without acquiring additional crew members.
The journey was arduous, characterized by unfavorable winds and a couple of strong gales, leaving the entire crew exhausted by the time they reached their destination.
At sunset, they anchored in a strikingly beautiful, land-locked gulf.

Their ship was immediately surrounded by local boats filled with people identified by the narrator as Negroes, Mexican Indians, and individuals of mixed heritage, all eager to sell fruits and vegetables or to dive for coins.

The sight of many cheerful faces, particularly those of the black people, the taste of tropical fruits, and especially the emerging lights of the town, offered a delightful contrast to their dark and violent experiences on the island.
The Doctor and the Squire, accompanied by Jim, went ashore to spend the early part of the night.

There, they encountered the captain of an English naval vessel, engaged in conversation, visited his ship, and enjoyed themselves so thoroughly that dawn was breaking when they returned to the Hispaniola.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Here they met the captain of an English man-of-war, fell in talk with him, went on board his ship, and, in short, had so agreeable a time that day was breaking when we came alongside the Hispaniola.

events.text_segment:
We were so short of men that everyone on board had to bear a hand—only the captain lying on a mattress in the stern and giving his orders, for though greatly recovered he was still in want of quiet. We laid her head for the nearest port in Spanish America, for we could not risk the voyage home without fresh hands; and as it was, what with baffling winds and a couple of fresh gales, we were all worn out before we reached it.
It was just at sundown when we cast anchor in a most beautiful land-locked gulf, and were immediately surrounded by shore boats full of Negroes and Mexican Indians and half-bloods selling fruits and vegetables and offering to dive for bits of money. The sight of so many good-humoured faces (especially the blacks), the taste of the tropical fruits, and above all the lights that began to shine in the town made a most charming contrast to our dark and bloody sojourn on the island; and the doctor and the squire, taking me along with them, went ashore to pass the early part of the night. Here they met the captain of an English man-of-war, fell in talk with him, went on board his ship, and, in short, had so agreeable a time that day was breaking when we came alongside the Hispaniola.

events.title: Silver's Cunning Escape with a Share of Treasure
detailed_summary: Upon their return to the Hispaniola, the shore party discovered Ben Gunn alone on deck.
With exaggerated movements and expressions, Ben Gunn confessed that Long John Silver had escaped.
He explained that he had facilitated Silver's departure in a shore boat some hours prior.
Ben Gunn justified his actions by claiming he did it to preserve their lives, suggesting that Silver's continued presence on board would have inevitably led to their demise.

It was further revealed that Silver had not left empty-handed; he had managed to discreetly cut through a bulkhead and abscond with one of the sacks of coins, estimated to be worth three or four hundred guineas, to aid his future travels.
Jim observed that the entire group felt a sense of relief at being rid of Silver, considering the stolen sum a relatively small price to pay for his permanent absence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Ben Gunn was on deck alone, and as soon as we came on board he began, with wonderful contortions, to make us a confession.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think we were all pleased to be so cheaply quit of him.

events.text_segment:
Ben Gunn was on deck alone, and as soon as we came on board he began, with wonderful contortions, to make us a confession. Silver was gone. The maroon had connived at his escape in a shore boat some hours ago, and he now assured us he had only done so to preserve our lives, which would certainly have been forfeit if “that man with the one leg had stayed aboard.” But this was not all. The sea-cook had not gone empty-handed. He had cut through a bulkhead unobserved and had removed one of the sacks of coin, worth perhaps three or four hundred guineas, to help him on his further wanderings.
I think we were all pleased to be so cheaply quit of him.

events.title: Return to Bristol and the Divergent Fates of the Survivors
detailed_summary: After recruiting a few new crew members, the Hispaniola had an uneventful voyage back to England, arriving in Bristol just as Mr. Blandly was contemplating dispatching a support vessel.
Only five of the original company who had set sail returned with her; the narrator attributes the loss of the others to vice and misfortune.
All the survivors received a generous share of the treasure, each using their newfound wealth according to their individual nature and wisdom.
Captain Smollett retired from his maritime career.

Gray not only conserved his money but, inspired by a newfound ambition, also diligently studied his profession, eventually becoming a mate and part-owner of a substantial ship, as well as marrying and starting a family.

Ben Gunn was given a thousand pounds, which he rapidly spent or lost within nineteen days, finding himself begging by the twentieth. He was then provided with a position as a lodge-keeper, as he had once feared on the island, and became a popular, though somewhat ridiculed, local character, known for his singing in church.

No further information about Long John Silver ever reached them. Jim expresses a hope that Silver reunited with his former black companion and perhaps lives comfortably, given that his prospects for spiritual comfort in the afterlife seemed slim.
Jim believes the remaining silver bars and weapons are still buried where Flint interred them, and he harbors no desire to ever revisit the accursed island.
He is persistently troubled by nightmares featuring the sound of the surf on its coasts and the terrifying memory of Captain Flint's characteristic exclamation concerning silver coins.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, to make a long story short, we got a few hands on board, made a good cruise home, and the Hispaniola reached Bristol just as Mr. Blandly was beginning to think of fitting out her consort.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!”

events.text_segment:
Well, to make a long story short, we got a few hands on board, made a good cruise home, and the Hispaniola reached Bristol just as Mr. Blandly was beginning to think of fitting out her consort. Five men only of those who had sailed returned with her. “Drink and the devil had done for the rest,” with a vengeance, although, to be sure, we were not quite in so bad a case as that other ship they sang about: With one man of her crew alive, What put to sea with seventy-five.
All of us had an ample share of the treasure and used it wisely or foolishly, according to our natures. Captain Smollett is now retired from the sea. Gray not only saved his money, but being suddenly smit with the desire to rise, also studied his profession, and he is now mate and part owner of a fine full-rigged ship, married besides, and the father of a family. As for Ben Gunn, he got a thousand pounds, which he spent or lost in three weeks, or to be more exact, in nineteen days, for he was back begging on the twentieth. Then he was given a lodge to keep, exactly as he had feared upon the island; and he still lives, a great favourite, though something of a butt, with the country boys, and a notable singer in church on Sundays and saints’ days.
Of Silver we have heard no more. That formidable seafaring man with one leg has at last gone clean out of my life; but I dare say he met his old Negress, and perhaps still lives in comfort with her and Captain Flint. It is to be hoped so, I suppose, for his chances of comfort in another world are very small.
The bar silver and the arms still lie, for all that I know, where Flint buried them; and certainly they shall lie there for me. Oxen and wain-ropes would not bring me back again to that accursed island; and the worst dreams that ever I have are when I hear the surf booming about its coasts or start upright in bed with the sharp voice of Captain Flint still ringing in my ears: “Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!”
